title: Utilities for Working with Age Categories
text: breaks_to_interval provides categorisation based specified breaks represent left-hand interval limits. resultant groupings span minimum break Inf always closed left open right. Ages minimum break returned NA. example, breaks = c(0, 1, 10, 30) interval categories [0, 1), [1, 10), [10, 30) [30, Inf). Intervals returned data frame 3 entries; factor character representation interval two columns representing numeric values corresponding lower (closed) upper (open) bounds.
code: library(ageutils) breaks_to_interval(breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L)) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf

title: Utilities for Working with Age Categories
text: cut_ages() provides categorisation ages based specified breaks represent left-hand interval limits. Categorisation based breaks follows approach breaks_to_interval.

title: Utilities for Working with Age Categories
text: split_interval_counts() splits counts within age interval counts individuals years based given weighting. Age intervals specified lower (closed) upper (open) bounds, .e. intervals form [lower, upper).
code: # by default counts are split equally across ages within intervals split_interval_counts(     lower_bounds = c(0L, 5L, 10L),     upper_bounds = c(5L, 10L, 20L),     counts = c(5L, 10L, 30L) ) #>    age count #> 1    0     1 #> 2    1     1 #> 3    2     1 #> 4    3     1 #> 5    4     1 #> 6    5     2 #> 7    6     2 #> 8    7     2 #> 9    8     2 #> 10   9     2 #> 11  10     3 #> 12  11     3 #> 13  12     3 #> 14  13     3 #> 15  14     3 #> 16  15     3 #> 17  16     3 #> 18  17     3 #> 19  18     3 #> 20  19     3  # Population weightings to apply for individual years can be specified by # the weights argument. If these are specified, they must be of length # `max_upper` and represent weights in the range 0:(max_upper - 1). max_upper <- 20L weights <- integer(max_upper) weights[c(TRUE, FALSE)] <- 1L split_interval_counts(     lower_bounds = c(0L, 5L, 10L),     upper_bounds = c(5L, 10L, 20L),     counts = c(5L, 10L, 30L),     max_upper = max_upper,     weights <- weights ) #>    age    count #> 1    0 1.666667 #> 2    1 0.000000 #> 3    2 1.666667 #> 4    3 0.000000 #> 5    4 1.666667 #> 6    5 0.000000 #> 7    6 5.000000 #> 8    7 0.000000 #> 9    8 5.000000 #> 10   9 0.000000 #> 11  10 6.000000 #> 12  11 0.000000 #> 13  12 6.000000 #> 14  13 0.000000 #> 15  14 6.000000 #> 16  15 0.000000 #> 17  16 6.000000 #> 18  17 0.000000 #> 19  18 6.000000 #> 20  19 0.000000

title: Utilities for Working with Age Categories
text: aggregate_age_counts() provides aggregation counts across ages (years). similar cut() tapply() pattern optimised speed flexibility. Groupings ages_to_interval() counts provided across natural numbers well missing values.
code: # default ages generated as 0:(length(counts) - 1L) if only counts provided. aggregate_age_counts(counts = 1:65, breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L)) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1     1 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5    14 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15   105 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25   205 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45   710 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65  1110 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf     0 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA     0  # Values below the minimum break are counted as NA aggregate_age_counts(counts = 1:65, breaks = 50L) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1 [50, Inf)          50         Inf   870 #> 2      <NA>          NA          NA  1275  # NA ages are also handled with their own grouping ages <- 1:65 ages[1:44] <- NA aggregate_age_counts(     counts = 1:65,     ages = ages,     breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L) ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1     0 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5     0 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15     0 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25     0 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45     0 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65  1090 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf    65 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA   990

title: Utilities for Working with Age Categories
text: reaggregate_interval_counts() equivalent , efficient call split_interval_counts() followed aggregate_age_counts(). example shows can used redistribute counts across desired set age intervals. use data included package obtained 2021 census modify based desired interval limits.
code: # census data data(pop_dat) pop_dat #>    area_code         area_name age_category   value #> 1  K04000001 England and Wales       [0, 5) 3232100 #> 2  K04000001 England and Wales      [5, 10) 3524600 #> 3  K04000001 England and Wales     [10, 15) 3595900 #> 4  K04000001 England and Wales     [15, 20) 3394700 #> 5  K04000001 England and Wales     [20, 25) 3602100 #> 6  K04000001 England and Wales     [25, 30) 3901800 #> 7  K04000001 England and Wales     [30, 35) 4148800 #> 8  K04000001 England and Wales     [35, 40) 3981600 #> 9  K04000001 England and Wales     [40, 45) 3755700 #> 10 K04000001 England and Wales     [45, 50) 3788700 #> 11 K04000001 England and Wales     [50, 55) 4123400 #> 12 K04000001 England and Wales     [55, 60) 4029000 #> 13 K04000001 England and Wales     [60, 65) 3455700 #> 14 K04000001 England and Wales     [65, 70) 2945100 #> 15 K04000001 England and Wales     [70, 75) 2978000 #> 16 K04000001 England and Wales     [75, 80) 2170300 #> 17 K04000001 England and Wales     [80, 85) 1517000 #> 18 K04000001 England and Wales     [85, 90)  925100 #> 19 K04000001 England and Wales    [90, Inf)  527900  # each row is for the same region so discard for moment dat <- subset(pop_dat, select = c(age_category, value))  # extract upper and lower bounds dat <- transform(     dat,     lower_bound = as.numeric(sub("\\[([0-9]+), .+)", "\\1", age_category)),     upper_bound = as.numeric(sub(".+, (.+))", "\\1", age_category)) )  head(dat, n=10) #>    age_category   value lower_bound upper_bound #> 1        [0, 5) 3232100           0           5 #> 2       [5, 10) 3524600           5          10 #> 3      [10, 15) 3595900          10          15 #> 4      [15, 20) 3394700          15          20 #> 5      [20, 25) 3602100          20          25 #> 6      [25, 30) 3901800          25          30 #> 7      [30, 35) 4148800          30          35 #> 8      [35, 40) 3981600          35          40 #> 9      [40, 45) 3755700          40          45 #> 10     [45, 50) 3788700          45          50  # recategorise based on ages with(     dat,     reaggregate_interval_counts(         lower_bounds = lower_bound,         upper_bounds = upper_bound,         counts = value,         breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L),         max_upper = 100L,         weights = NULL     ) ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound    count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1   646420 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5  2585680 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15  7120500 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25  6996800 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45 15787900 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65 15396800 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf 11063400 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA        0

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tim Taylor. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Taylor T (2023). ageutils: Collection Functions Working Age Intervals. R package version 0.0.1.9000, https://timtaylor.github.io/ageutils/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ageutils: Collection of Functions for Working with Age Intervals},   author = {Tim Taylor},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.1.9000},   url = {https://timtaylor.github.io/ageutils/}, }

what: Collection of Functions for Working with Age Intervals
title: Collection of Functions for Working with Age Intervals
text: {ageutils} provides collection efficient functions working individual ages corresponding intervals. include functions efficient conversion age interval, aggregation ages associated counts intervals splitting interval counts based specified age distributions. Note similar functionality /found {ympes} package. Going forward, intention functionality removed {ympes} favour , focussed, package. can install released version {ageutils} CRAN : development version {ageutils} can installed GitHub :

title: Utilities for Age Intervals — ageutils
text: help page documents utility functions provided working individual ages associated intervals: breaks_to_interval() takes specified set breaks representing left hand limits closed open interval, .e [x, y), returns corresponding interval upper bounds. resulting intervals span minimum break Inf. cut_ages() provides categorisation ages based specified breaks represent left-hand interval limits. resultant groupings span minimum break Inf always closed left open right. Ages minimum break returned NA. example, breaks = c(0, 1, 10, 30) possible groupings [0, 1), [1, 10), [10, 30) [30, Inf). roughly comparable call cut(ages, right = FALSE, breaks = c(limits, Inf)) resultant interval start end points returned entries list. split_interval_counts() splits counts given age interval counts individual years based given weighting. Age intervals specified lower (closed) upper (open) bounds, .e. intervals form [lower, upper). aggregate_age_counts() provides aggregation counts across ages (years). similar cut() tapply() pattern optimised speed flexibility. Groupings ages_to_interval() counts provided across natural numbers grater minimum break. Missing values, less minimum break, grouped NA. reaggregate_interval_counts() equivalent , efficient , call split_interval_counts() followed aggregate_age_counts().

title: Utilities for Age Intervals — ageutils
code: breaks_to_interval(breaks)  cut_ages(ages, breaks)  split_interval_counts(   lower_bounds,   upper_bounds,   counts,   max_upper = 100L,   weights = NULL )  aggregate_age_counts(counts, ages = 0:(length(counts) - 1L), breaks)  reaggregate_interval_counts(   lower_bounds,   upper_bounds,   counts,   breaks,   max_upper = 100L,   weights = NULL )

title: Utilities for Age Intervals — ageutils
text: breaks [numeric]. 1 non-negative cut points increasing (strictly) order. correspond left hand side desired intervals (e.g. closed side [x, y). Double values coerced integer prior categorisation. ages [numeric]. Vector age years. Double values coerced integer prior categorisation / aggregation. aggregate_age_counts(), must corresponding counts entry defaults 0:(N-1) N number counts present. ages >= 200 permitted due internal implementation. lower_bounds, upper_bounds [integerish]. pair vectors representing bounds intervals. lower_bounds must strictly less upper_bounds greater equal zero. Missing (NA) bounds permitted. Double vectors coerced integer. counts [numeric]. Vector counts aggregated. max_upper [integerish] Represents maximum upper bounds permitted upon splitting data. Used replace Inf upper bounds prior splitting. upper_bound greater max_upper function error. Double vectors coerced integer. weights [numeric] Population weightings apply individual years. NULL (default) counts split evenly based interval size. specified, must length max_upper represent weights range 0:(max_upper - 1).

title: Utilities for Age Intervals — ageutils
text: breaks_to_interval() cut_ages(): data frame ordered factor column (interval), well columns corresponding explicit bounds (lower_bound upper_bound). split_interval_counts(): data frame entries age (years) count. aggregate_age_counts() reaggregate_interval_counts(): data frame 4 entries; interval, lower_bound, upper_bound associated count.

title: Utilities for Age Intervals — ageutils
code: cut_ages(ages = 0:9, breaks = c(0L, 3L, 5L, 10L)) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound #> 1    [0, 3)           0           3 #> 2    [0, 3)           0           3 #> 3    [0, 3)           0           3 #> 4    [3, 5)           3           5 #> 5    [3, 5)           3           5 #> 6   [5, 10)           5          10 #> 7   [5, 10)           5          10 #> 8   [5, 10)           5          10 #> 9   [5, 10)           5          10 #> 10  [5, 10)           5          10 cut_ages(ages = 0:9, breaks = 5L) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound #> 1      <NA>          NA          NA #> 2      <NA>          NA          NA #> 3      <NA>          NA          NA #> 4      <NA>          NA          NA #> 5      <NA>          NA          NA #> 6  [5, Inf)           5         Inf #> 7  [5, Inf)           5         Inf #> 8  [5, Inf)           5         Inf #> 9  [5, Inf)           5         Inf #> 10 [5, Inf)           5         Inf  split_interval_counts(     lower_bounds = c(0, 5, 10),     upper_bounds = c(5, 10, 20),     counts = c(5, 10, 30) ) #>    age count #> 1    0     1 #> 2    1     1 #> 3    2     1 #> 4    3     1 #> 5    4     1 #> 6    5     2 #> 7    6     2 #> 8    7     2 #> 9    8     2 #> 10   9     2 #> 11  10     3 #> 12  11     3 #> 13  12     3 #> 14  13     3 #> 15  14     3 #> 16  15     3 #> 17  16     3 #> 18  17     3 #> 19  18     3 #> 20  19     3  # default ages generated if only counts provided (here ages will be 0:64) aggregate_age_counts(counts = 1:65, breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L)) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1     1 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5    14 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15   105 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25   205 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45   710 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65  1110 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf     0 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA     0 aggregate_age_counts(counts = 1:65, breaks = 50L) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1 [50, Inf)          50         Inf   870 #> 2      <NA>          NA          NA  1275  # NA ages are handled with their own grouping ages <- 1:65; ages[1:44] <- NA aggregate_age_counts(     counts = 1:65,     ages = ages,     breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L) ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1     0 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5     0 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15     0 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25     0 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45     0 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65  1090 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf    65 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA   990  reaggregate_interval_counts(     lower_bounds = c(0, 5, 10),     upper_bounds = c(5, 10, 20),     counts = c(5, 10, 30),     breaks = c(0L, 1L, 5L, 15L, 25L, 45L, 65L) ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound count #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1     1 #> 2    [1, 5)           1           5     4 #> 3   [5, 15)           5          15    25 #> 4  [15, 25)          15          25    15 #> 5  [25, 45)          25          45     0 #> 6  [45, 65)          45          65     0 #> 7 [65, Inf)          65         Inf     0 #> 8      <NA>          NA          NA     0

title: Aggregated population data — pop_dat
text: dataset derived 2021 UK census containing population different age categories across England Wales.

title: Aggregated population data — pop_dat
text: data frame 200 rows 6 variables: area_code Unique area identifier area_name Unique area name age_category Left-closed right-open age interval value count individ

title: Aggregated population data — pop_dat
text: https://github.com/TimTaylor/census_pop_2021

what: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
title: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
text: Reaggregate rates across interval

title: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
code: reaggregate_interval_rates(   lower_bounds,   upper_bounds = NULL,   rates,   breaks,   max_upper = 150L,   weights = NULL )

title: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
text: lower_bounds, upper_bounds [integerish]. pair vectors representing bounds current intervals. upper_bounds NULL, automatically set c(lower_bounds[-1L], max_upper). lower_bounds must strictly less upper_bounds greater equal zero. Missing (NA) bounds permitted. Double vectors coerced integer. rates [numeric]. Vector counts averaged. breaks [numeric]. 1 non-negative cut points increasing (strictly) order. correspond left hand side desired intervals (e.g. closed side [x, y). Double values coerced integer prior categorisation. max_upper [integerish] Represents maximum upper bounds permitted upon splitting data. Used replace Inf upper bounds prior splitting. upper_bound greater max_upper function error. Double vectors coerced integer. weights [numeric] Population weightings apply individual years. NULL (default) rates split based interval size. specified, must length max_upper represent weights range 0:(max_upper - 1).

title: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
text: data frame 4 entries; interval, lower_bound, upper_bound associated count.

title: Reaggregate rates across an interval — reaggregate_interval_rates
code: reaggregate_interval_rates(   lower_bounds = c(0, 5, 13),   upper_bounds= c(5, 15, 100),   rates = c(1, 0.1, 0.01),   breaks = c(0, 1, 9, 15),   weights = round(runif(70, 10, 30)) ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound      rate #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1 1.0000000 #> 2    [1, 9)           1           9 0.5153846 #> 3   [9, 15)           9          15 0.0737500 #> 4 [15, 150)          15         150 0.0100000  reaggregate_interval_rates(   lower_bounds = c(0, 5, 13),   rates = c(1, 0.1, 0.01),   breaks = c(0, 1, 9, 15),   weights = round(runif(70, 10, 30)),   max_upper = 100 ) #>    interval lower_bound upper_bound       rate #> 1    [0, 1)           0           1 1.00000000 #> 2    [1, 9)           1           9 0.54645669 #> 3   [9, 15)           9          15 0.06785714 #> 4 [15, 100)          15         100 0.01000000

title: ageutils (development version)
text: Documentation formatting.

title: ageutils 0.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-01-09 Initial release ageutils provides collection efficient functions working individual ages corresponding intervals. include functions efficient conversion age interval, aggregation ages associated counts intervals splitting interval counts based specified age distributions. Functions derived ympes intention remove functions package favour one going forward.
